items.title: Hamas should release 20 remaining hostages as part of peace deal
items.standfirst: The first phase of the peace deal between Israel and Hamas should see Hamas release the 20 remaining living hostages it is still holding, though Hamas has said it will take more time to recover the remains of the hostages who died while in captivity. NBC News' Richard Engel reports.
items.content: The first phase of the peace deal between Israel and Hamas should see Hamas release the 20 remaining living hostages it is still holding, though Hamas has said it will take more time to recover the remains of the hostages who died while in captivity. NBC News' Richard Engel reports.

items.title: Trump says Israel, Hamas agree to Gaza deal
Israel and Hamas agree to first phase of peace plan, Trump says
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas have struck a deal for Hamas to release all remaining hostages and for Israel to withdraw its forces to an "agreed upon line," President Trump announced, calling it the "first phase" of a peace deal to end the two-year-long war. Ed O'Keefe and Debora Patta have more.
items.content: Israel and Hamas have struck a deal for Hamas to release all remaining hostages and for Israel to withdraw its forces to an "agreed upon line," President Trump announced, calling it the "first phase" of a peace deal to end the two-year-long war. Ed O'Keefe and Debora Patta have more.

items.title: Israel and Hamas agree to first phase of deal to end Gaza war
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of a deal to end the two-year-long war in Gaza. The deal would include the release of all remaining hostages in exchange for Israel's partial withdrawal from Gaza. Nick Schifrin reports.
items.content: Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of a deal to end the two-year-long war in Gaza. The deal would include the release of all remaining hostages in exchange for Israel's partial withdrawal from Gaza. Nick Schifrin reports.

Continue reading...

The deal involves the release of hostages and a withdrawal of troops.

The CBS Evening News and BBC World also reported on the agreement.

items.title: Former FBI head James Comey pleads not guilty in Justice Department case pushed by Trump
items.standfirst: Former FBI director James Comey pleaded not guilty on Wednesday to criminal charges accusing him of making false statements to Congress and obstructing a congressional investigation, in the first prosecution by the Justice Departmant against one of US President Donald Trump's political foes. Comey faces up to five years in prison if he is convicted.
items.content: Former FBI director James Comey pleaded not guilty on Wednesday to criminal charges accusing him of making false statements to Congress and obstructing a congressional investigation, in the first prosecution by the Justice Departmant against one of US President Donald Trump's political foes. Comey faces up to five years in prison if he is convicted.

ai_summary: James Comey pleaded not guilty to charges of lying to Congress.
A trial date was set for January 5, according to CBS News.
Comey's legal team argues the case is politically motivated.
The Justice Department is prosecuting Comey, pushed by Trump.
Comey faces up to five years in prison if convicted of the charges.

items.title: Outgoing French PM says will present draft budget next Monday
items.standfirst: France's caretaker Prime Minister S√©bastien Lecornu said he'd present a draft bill next Monday, adding that there was "a lot to debate" on the bill. Among the sticking points is President Emmanuel Macron's signature pension reform passed in 2023. So could it possibly be suspended? If so, at what cost? Also in the segment, as the price of gold surges past $4,000/oz, we take a look at the reasons behind the record rally.
items.content: France's caretaker Prime Minister S√©bastien Lecornu said he'd present a draft bill next Monday, adding that there was "a lot to debate" on the bill. Among the sticking points is President Emmanuel Macron's signature pension reform passed in 2023. So could it possibly be suspended? If so, at what cost? Also in the segment, as the price of gold surges past $4,000/oz, we take a look at the reasons behind the record rally.

items.title: French political turmoil 'being regarded with considerable horror' in Europe, analyst says
items.standfirst: The outgoing French prime minister said Wednesday that he expects President Emmanuel Macron to name his replacement in the next 48 hours. Speaking with FRANCE 24's Yinka Oyetade, Quentin Peel, former foreign editor at the Financial Times, says that France's political turmoil is 'being regarded with considerable horror' in European capitals.
items.content: The outgoing French prime minister said Wednesday that he expects President Emmanuel Macron to name his replacement in the next 48 hours. Speaking with FRANCE 24's Yinka Oyetade, Quentin Peel, former foreign editor at the Financial Times, says that France's political turmoil is 'being regarded with considerable horror' in European capitals.

items.title: Outgoing French PM says ‚Äòpath still exists‚Äô to avoid snap elections
items.standfirst: S√©bastien Lecornu says majority of MPs willing to seek agreement on budget and avoid further instabilityFrance‚Äôs caretaker prime minister, S√©bastien Lecornu, has said a majority of MPs ‚Äúrejects the idea‚Äù of snap elections and that ‚Äúa path still exists‚Äù that should allow Emmanuel Macron to appoint a new premier within 48 hours.‚ÄúSeveral groups are willing to seek agreement on a budget‚Äù for 2026, Lecornu told France 2 public television on Wednesday, and were making clear their ‚Äúconditions‚Äù. Talks would be difficult, he said, but ‚Äúthe prospect of a dissolution [of parliament] is fading‚Äù. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Jonathan Rinderknecht allegedly started blaze that destroyed over 6,800 structures in CaliforniaA 29-year-old man has been arrested and charged with igniting the fire that days later became the devastating Palisades blaze, which killed 12 people and destroyed more than 6,800 structures in one of the most destructive wildfires in Los Angeles history.Jonathan Rinderknecht was arrested near his Florida residence on federal charges of destruction of property by means of fire, acting US attorney for the central district of California, Bill Essayli, announced on Wednesday. No motive was presented. Continue reading...

items.title: Man arrested over deadly January fire in Los Angeles
items.standfirst: Authorities investigating the deadly Palisades Fire that tore through an affluent Los Angeles suburb in January said Wednesday they had arrested a man who they believe started the blaze. Jonathan Rinderknecht, 29, was taken into custody in Florida, on suspicion of destruction of property by means of fire, Acting United States Attorney Bill Essayli said. FRANCE 24's Wassim Cornet reports from Los Angeles.
items.content: Authorities investigating the deadly Palisades Fire that tore through an affluent Los Angeles suburb in January said Wednesday they had arrested a man who they believe started the blaze.
